comments.commentBody: How  'bout those Lobos Wags?

Noel, the Lobos (or is it Bobos?)  were not the team I had going deep that lost yesterday, it was Georgetown.  But the collective grief on that upset around here is amazing, isn't it?  But of course the rest of the vaunted MWC is doing well.  Oh, wait a minute . . .

The puzzle came up at a point when I had started to overdose on basketball, (and my brackets are trashed, another story) so I settled in with David and my pen and fell into all the misdirects already mentioned by 530 and Deb.  A good diversion from hoops, though.

If the Yankees hold Derek Jeter out of major league spring training games, he won't be ready to play come opening day.  The idea of limiting him to minor league games -- so that IF he goes on the DL when the regular season starts, his stay on the DL will be shorter -- is overthinking a problem to the point of creating another one.  Cashman must have hit his head when he landed after that parachute jump, because he isn't acting rationally.

In the original posting, the Professor took the trouble to explain the identicalness of the Zombie and the principal as identical down to the subatomic nature of being, presumably to energy levels, locations of the pieces, their momenta, etc. (all of which would violate the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, but that was his description, not mine). Then he says that the Zombie did not share the principal's "experiences." So what? If I pump the same number of electrons into the charge wells of flash memory, or the magnetic domains into a magnetic tape, I have encoded the original "experiences" into the copy, and who's to tell the difference? How does one deny that the Zombie has consciousness and experience if he thinks he (it?) has them. Isn't this another example of the philosophical thought experiment of "we all came into being 5 minutes ago with implanted memories of decades of life and experience?

The ability of "consciousness" is encoded into our neural system. Clearly one's consciousness can be impaired by physical injury, which suggests a physical base.

I still think the Professor's argument is circular.

And Mary finally has the ability to "experience" what people are TRAINED to recognize as RED, an ability no more remarkable than never before having tasted fennel or spinach because it was never offered to them and now being able to recognize it when it is encountered later. The sensation has been logged.

Music as in what we actually experience? Or music as in the scientific description? The former is simply the same problem reinstated. We don't find music inside the tape recorder for the same reason we don't find consciousness in the brain -- namely because consciousness and conscious experiences (music in this case) are not physical.

If the latter then of course music can be found in the tape recorder. All physical phenomena are reducible. Only consciousness isn't.

Gutting has not denied that experiences "arise from the physical brain" so I'm not sure why you're making this point. What the arguments considered purport to establish is just what you have said, that "experiences may not be physical." In that case it is wrong to claim that mental experiences are the very same as physical phenomenon, neuronal activity, brain firings, etc. in the body. So it seems you are in agreement with the professor on the central point of his article. You also seem to provide support for the professor when you note that "introspection reveals nothing about how the brain actually works." If right this means that our mental awareness of ourselves is not an awareness of any neuronal or brain activity going on. This would suggest that our mental awareness needs to be explicated in other terms.

We're asked to imagine a zombie that is identical to us, but different, in that it doesn't have "experiences." Therefore, consciousness is non-physical. Both this argument and the one featuring Mary assume what they set out to prove, like a magician sneaking a ball under the cup and then revealing that the ball has magically appeared.

We shouldn't be surprised that introspecting about our own consciousness produces such circular results. After all, our brains swarm with electrical impulses jumping from synapse to synapse, but we don't see the impulses coming from our eyes, we see images. Introspection reveals nothing about how the brain actually works, so we might want to be cautious when introspecting about something as abstract as consciousness.

If you take apart a tape recorder, you will not find music inside. If you take apart the brain, you will not find experiences amid the synapses. Music emerges from the operation of the tape recorder much as consciousness emerges from the operation of the brain. Electrically stimulate the brain, and you can elicit a memory, an image, or an emotion. These experiences may not be "physical," but they arise from the physical brain.

Consciousness is mysterious, but it's not miraculous. If it were, everything we know about biology, chemistry and physics would be wrong. Yet these disciplines are our best hope for finally understanding how the mind emerges from the brain.

Woody Johnson is not a smart owner. The best thing he could do is leave the management of the team up to the people he hired and keep his mouth shut. If he doesn't watch himself Revis won't sign anything until after the season, if he's smart he'd feign multiple injuries and get out most of the last year of his contract and then take his talent somewhere where' he is going to get paid. I wonder if Idzik is scratching his head yet with his owner popping off during Free Agency. Other players watch this stuff too and it jades peoples opinions about coming to play for the Jets. Put a sock in it Woody.

Person killed by guns since Newtown can be found here.

http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/crime/2012/12/gun_death_...

Beautiful full circle of discourse on slowing or halting senseless gun violence. There is a great deal of pain in the fiber of our nation being since Newtown. It should not be that way.

Accepted leaders, whatever their affiliation, stand in the crossfire political debate and do nothing while the deaths mount, making an atrocity on the scale of our greatest tragedies, at least 2883 killed. A daily onslaught

Love reading this type of article, makes me feel better, even though I know the Republicans are plotting to manipulate the way election results are dispensed, and that are government is held hostage by one political party is a travesty. The Republicans lost the election for President, lost seats in both houses in Congress and yet their agenda by way of the Sequester is put in place?

Anyone that thinks the GOP is dead in the water, wakeup, I wouldn't be surprised to see another President elected with a minority of votes.

So, given the validity of your statement that there "is no reason 30 states should be under GOP control," WHY are they?  Why hasn't the Democratic President been a better advocate for those policies the party has put forward that support the vast majority of voters - whether they know it or not.  Where is the Democratic equivalent of the ubiquitous Fox News and its cousins?  The politics bookshelves at my local Barnes & Noble are full to overflowing with books churned out to support Republican distortions and fantasies - not to mention Republican viciousness and slander.  There are many good books that stick to facts and end up supporting primarily Democratic viewpoints and policy initiatives, but it seems without some vituperative “edginess” they get very restricted audiences.  A recent study showed how strong the influence of mocking, negative comments can be on readers of the articles at which the comments were directed.  It seems that this effect, along with an ugly tendency to want to feel better about one’s self by putting less fortunate people down, is pushing too many people into the Republican ranks.  I don’t know how rational, fact-based people counter this – and, apparently, neither does the Democratic leadership…unless the Democratic leadership really has already been bought by the wealthy individuals and corporations that pull the strings behind too much of our government these days.
I think Sherry Wacker should add another reason:  voters don't care

Well, I wish republicans were, indeed, having trouble. They are making life so miserable in the states, I'm going to have to move myself! How many ways can they legislate women's bodies, and worker right? In MI, not content with their stealthyily assed right to work laws, they now want to defund two major universities by 20% for not complying with a law that's yet to take effect. Bastards!

There is no reason 30 states should be under GOP control. None.

After checking the open secrets website, I was happy to find that none of my reps here in Ct. were on the list as having been purchased by the NRA. However, I could not find any information about the National Sports shooting Foundation whose headquarters are in Newton.

Would that it were so simple as NRA.

Look at Harry Reid, himself a gun enthusiast, undermining the legislation and refusing to allow bills to be brought to the floor despite their congruence with the wishes of 70% of Americans.

There are many others like him on both sides of the aisle. It's partly personal belief, partly from which lobby their bread is buttered, and partly (in the West and South) the preferences of their base.

The gun-grabbers create a bete-noire and then want their believers to knock it down.

The idea that six guys at the NRA control the minds of 60 senators and 300 congressmen is hilarious on its face.

In fact, the opponents of the gun-grabbers are none other than a huge slice of the American public.

We don't have more gun control because The People don't want it, not because the NRA tells them not to want it.

The other absurd idea is that the polls cited by gun-grabbers accurately reflect the thinking of the public. Those polls have remained largely unchanged for 40 years and yet.....and yet....somehow the gun-grabbers still come up with the short end of the stick when all the votes are in.

There are many things that we could do to reduce the carnage that is caused by gun violence every year. Examples include closing the gun show loophole, banning assault weapons and ammunition clips larger than 10 bullets, getting armor piercing bullets off the streets, ending the freeze on gun violence research, requiring gun personalization technology, and requiring gun owners to have liability insurance. And these steps are popular, enjoying support from the vast majority of Americans.

So, why hasn't Congress acted? Because of the NRA and other gun industry front groups that have taken increasingly extreme positions against even mild gun safety legislation. These groups spend virtually unlimited amounts of gun industry money lobbying against gun safety laws, and targeting for electoral defeat any politician who dares to stand up against gun violence.

The only way to overcome the NRA and its allies is for all of us to demand that our elected officials answer to us, not the NRA. And doing so requires us calling our members of Congress, writing letters to the editors of our local newspapers, joining organizations like the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, and urging our family and friends to do the same. We can win this issue and reduce gun violence in the US, but only if we all get involved.

www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

"Try as I might, I just can't see the deliberate cruel calculated misogyny or the genome-embedded racism and narcissism I see in Romney, Cruz, West, Gingrich, Walsh, Malkin, Coulter, Palin."

You should! She'd have all of America's Muslims interned in the blink of an eye. Remember what she tried to do to former Secretary of State Clinton's assistant, Huma Abedin based only on her heritage? John McCain stepped in to defend Huma. Bachmann has, in the past, tried to start a McCarthy-style House Un-American Activities Committee.

She and Steve King are birds of the same feathers as Wisconsin's own Joseph McCarthy.

See http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/06/rep-steve-king-mccarthyism-pane...

Uh, while I agree with you, you must ask the question, "Where did they come from?" They were voted in by enough people, which should give pause at who the voters are. Much of American has become so uneducated, that they are now voting in, and tolerating imbeciles in government - the government that is a reflection of its people. Remember, "We the people...?"

You don't need to lament the deaths of Gilbert and Sullivan.  We have the creators of South Park and The Book of Mormon, we have Jon Stewart, and we have Stephen Colbert.  They will roast the GOP just fine.
If the Republicans "...fix it." they'd become Democrats, and I'm pretty sure this is not a crowd I'd want to spend with, no matter how big the tent.

Charles, leave the GOP alone, do not give them an idea of what they really are. They might just try to fix it.

I like them just as they are, examples of some of the most idiotic group of politicians I have seen in my lifetime. It is too bad we do not have Gilbert and Sullivan to write a light opera bout them, it would be hilarious.

There seems to be some sort of mental deficiency with them. If there are any real serious Republicans around, they do not want to let you know them, they are too embarrassed to admit they belong to the party. If you read the comments in the Sacramento Bee, you can tell immediately which are the conservatives by their ignorance of history, their inability to engage in rational argument, their slavish beliefs that Liberals are out to put them in concentration camps, and all sorts of conspiracy theories.

Bachmann is just one of the mentally disturbed, and that she and the others even have followers is indicative of just what substandard mentalities they are.
William F. Buckley must be mortified if he can view this current crop of graduates from the funny farm.

We can call this McGovern's revenge.

Hmmm, I didn't get a sense that he was bragging at all. I found the author's attitude refreshingly relaxed, yet not to the extent of being negligently disinterested in being a good parent (given that he reads and writes about parenting).

I'm also inclined to agree with the author's potentially controversial generalization that dads are more relaxed parents than moms, but would welcome further analysis of this. It seems to me that society places far greater pressure on women to be good parents - this makes it more difficult (guilt-inducing) for mothers to have a relaxed approach to parenting.
You're welcome here in sunny California, Josy! Come on down!
There are benefits to be allied with the US. It's as simple as that.

Because the Turks have never had the intention of destroying Israel.  That's why.  Makes things a lot easier, you know.  And come to think of it, if he can broker a peace between Turkey and Israel, why not settle the Kashmir dispute between your country and Pakistan.  Ah, but that's a totally different story, yes?

Because the problems are less complicated. i do think we should do more in Syria(like a no fly zone) but the last time that Obama did something like this the Republicans claimed he over reached his authority and didn't take the absolute lead as well(they didn't like being under Nato command)...

If Obama could broker peace between Turkey and Israel, and persuade the Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu to apologise with his Turkish counterpart, Erdogan on the two year long dispute, how come he didn't do the same with regard to the Israel-Palestine issue, despite his protestations to that end? Is it because Turkey seems emerging a crucial strategic ally in the new game being played in the Middle East, specially against Syria, and its strongman Assad- a sore in western eyes, while the President Abbas of the truncated Palestine nation could be kept waiting for attending to his political grievances against Netanyahu and his colonial expansion in the West Bank?

Fully agree.  Lots of good soccer fans in Colorado, but spring and fall weather there is notoriously unpredictable, very easy - too easy -  to have snow.  Costa Rica players and fans, and the US players and fans, deserved better - a real soccer match, international level play between two excellent teams - not a weather event where people played some soccer.

Yew arils are very pretty:
http://tinyurl.com/yewarils

They're the only part of the plant that isn't toxic. The little seed inside is deadly so dining on yew arils isn't recommended.

When there's a free kick, players are clearing off a spot to place the ball. This is the wrong approach. If you've ever seen beach soccer, when THEY get a free kick, they build a small mound of sand on which to place the ball atop. That's what they should be doing so they can get under the ball and hit it in the air.
Rona Barrett is still kicking.

This is not a cold weather game.  This is SNOW.  Inches of snow.  The game had no semblance to a WC qualifier.  It was a joke.  My buddies in the park could have played against either the Costa Ricans or the Americans with a similar result if we played in those conditions.  If the goal hadn't come in the first 15 or 20 minutes, it never would have come at all.
Somebody wisely pointed out that 5 or 6 Costa Rican players are on Norwegian or Denmark teams...  They're used to cold weather as well...
The snow is part of it ... quit complaining. Full credit to the CR players for wanting to continue the match. Vital win for the US, but I fear a group-stage exit in Brazil.

The real issue, as you imply here, is: What difference does consciousness make to our behavior? If it makes no difference, then we are just along for the ride - a conclusion I find depressing. If, however, consciousness makes a difference, then the zombie is impossible - lacking consciousness it could not have led the same life we have led.

I believe that part of the problem is we have never really interacted with a being that does not have some degree of consciousness - Other humans certainly, but I would guess that consciousness is not an all-or nothing thing. I think that all the higher animals have it to some degree, and that consciousness has evolved along with intelligence.

This could be a wedge for scientific and philosophical investigation - what behavioral difference would the absence of consciousness make? Could we perhaps build an intelligent but not conscious machine, or are thought and consciousness inextricably linked?

But all this does nothing to dent the zombie argument.

The point is this -- the measurable objective properties of physical events seem to be sufficient to wholly explain the totality of our behaviour.

Materialists don't disagree with this, but since consciousness *is the very same thing* as particular brain events, then given the physical events, consciousness necessarily follows. Hence p-zombies are *metaphysically impossible*.

But materialists don't give any arguments as to why consciousness is *entailed* given particular physical events (rather than merely caused).

"the Zombie Argument...eliminates only laws connecting physical make-up to experiences. Eliminating these laws eliminates only the experiences correlated with my zombie-twin’s physical make-up. It does nothing to that physical make-up itself."

But I know that my own experiences are the results of expriencings, that they are the outcomes of that long series of past experiencings that I call "living," and that those experiencings correlate to physical processes involving my whole body including my central nervous system. if my "zombie twin" is identical to me--in his alternate universe going through an identical series of physical processes to those I have referred to as "experiencings" but without any experience (ie., consciousness) correlated with those physical processes--then my "consciousness," my "experience," contributes nothing at all to the physical activity of living since an identical being to myself, having gone through a series of events identical to those that have shaped my experiencings, would jave lived a life identical to my own. if, then, the zombie has lived a life identical to my own, and since by definition the zombie has no consciousness, what I call my consciousness has been rendered entirely otiose. Nothing but an epiphenomenon. The zombie argument, if admitted, proves not that consciousness is non-physical but rather that it is nonexistent!

@WP

Mr. Blow quoted Mr. Kohut of Pew directly from his Washington Post piece. The reference to McCarthy and McGovern appears in quotes in the paragraph I am pasting below.

"Andrew Kohut, the founding director of the Pew Research Center, pointed out in The Washington Post on Friday that the party’s ratings “now stand at a 20-year low,” and that is in part because “the outsize influence of hard-line elements in the party base is doing to the G.O.P. what supporters of Gene McCarthy and George McGovern did to the Democratic Party in the late 1960s and early 1970s — radicalizing its image and standing in the way of its revitalization.”"

This is not a cold weather game.  This is SNOW.  Inches of snow.  The game had no semblance to a WC qualifier.  It was a joke.  My buddies in the park could have played against either the Costa Ricans or the Americans with a similar result if we played in those conditions.  If the goal hadn't come in the first 15 or 20 minutes, it never would have come at all.

All the gratuitous invectives are meaningless in the face of a single life saved by the legitimate use of guns in self-defense.

Every year, 180,000 individuals legitimately use guns in self-defense (TIME magazine, 1-28-2013, p.38)

Until the anti-gunners cease being intellectually-dishonest and ignoring the life-saving aspects of gun ownership, the normal folks will just keep on renewing their NRA membership, as they should.

If you think Sen. Hagan of North Carolina isn't scared right now you don't read the newspapers well. There are seven US senators running next year in RED states. That's what Harry Reid is protecting, his Democrat majority. He's scared.
The NRA is a legalized criminal organization. All the guys in Congress are afraid. The women not so much.

When Barack Obama became serious about politics the first thing he did was to become a community organizer. I believe that he has not stopped being that same community organizer to this day, only that his "communities" have gotten much larger.

In his speech to the Israeli audience he told them that the opportunities for change only begins once you have made the decision to do so. A commitment to make peace signals the beginning of hard work that lies ahead. A commitment that requires a large measure of hope to endure predictable setbacks and inevitable failures along the way.

This theme is exactly what Barack Obama has told the American people from the very first time he introduced himself. It is still exactly the same message that he conveys when he speaks to America.

We did not achieve the promises of hope and change when we elected Barack Obama as our president. The opportunity to reach those promises started on the day he was elected.

I am a proud American to see our president be so well received and to read the responses from these future leaders of Israel. The responsibility to effect those changes are not only on our political leaders, the bulk of that responsibility lies with the average citizens of our countries.

President Obama has always been quick to say, "Ordinary people doing extraordinary things." This holds true not only in America but anywhere else around the world.
Obama is stellar at speaking to and inspiring young people. I hope those he inspires will have the motivation, courage, and support to step forward and make a difference.

President Obama is a transformational figure. How he enthused the youth (both Palestinian and Israeli) to think this way is truly amazing.

The future of our world lies with the youth and their thoughts published here are so exhilarating. After all tomorrow's world is theirs to live in.

It will be a better place if the older generation will step aside and let the youth take the lead.

Thank you Mr. President for inspiring them this way.
